data.title: MEG Energy meeting on Cenovus deal postponed another week
data.description:
MEG Energy (OTCPK:MEGEF) said Friday its special shareholders meeting to vote on Cenovus Energy's (CVE) takeover proposal has been rescheduled to November 6 to allow time to disclose more information on asset sales.

MEG (OTCPK:MEGEF) Chairman James McFarland adjourned an investor meeting Thursday in Calgary after hours of delay, deferring a vote that had been scheduled for 9 a.m. Calgary time because of a "regulatory inquiry" that the company did not explain; it was the third time MEG has set a new date for the meeting.

Earlier this week, Cenovus (CVE) increased its takeover offer C$30/share in cash or 1.255 Cenovus shares for each MEG (OTCPK:MEGEF) share in order to secure the support of Strathcona Resources (OTCPK:STHRF), MEG's biggest shareholder; as part of the announcement, Cenovus said it was selling some assets in Saskatchewan and Alberta to Strathcona for C$150 million.

Strathcona (OTCPK:STHRF) kicked off the bidding war in May with an unsolicited bid that was opposed by the MEG (OTCPK:MEGEF) board.

data.title: AutoNation announces additional up to $1B share repurchase authorization
data.description:
AutoNation (AN) said on Friday that the automotive retailer's board has authorized an additional up to $1B stock buyback program.

Year-to-date through October 30, the company has repurchased 3M shares for an aggregate purchase price of $576M, or $189 per share.

The company said it now has ~$1.28B authorization remaining for share repurchases.

AutoNation had ~36M shares outstanding as of October 30, and has reduced its shares outstanding by 8% since December 31, 2024.

data.title: Battery Mineral Resources appoints new CFO
data.description:
• Battery Mineral Resources (BMR:CA) (BTRMF) appoints Jennifer Fulton Anderson as chief financial officer.
  • Current CFO Max Satel to depart the company effective October 31, 2025.
  • Fulton Anderson previously worked in equity research and investment banking at Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs.

data.title: Dallas Fed's Logan would have preferred no rate change
data.description:
Dallas Fed President Lori Logan said on Friday the U.S. economic outlook didn't call for cutting rates, as inflation "appears likely to exceed the FOMC’s 2% target for too much longer."

"The labor market remains balanced and cooling slowly. Inflation remains too high, taxing the budgets of businesses and families," she will say, according to prepared remarks at a Dallas Fed conference on The Evolving Landscape of Bank Funding. Logan isn't a voting member of the Federal Reserve's policymaking arm this  year.

Logan's view highlights the shifting and diverging views of the Federal Open Market Committee's members. Most of the voting members agreed to cut the federal funds rate target range by 25 basis points on Wednesday, but Kansas City Fed President Jeffrey Schmid voted to keep the rate unchanged, while Federal Reserve Governor Stephen Miran sought to cut the rate by 50 bps.

Furthermore, she said she'd find it "difficult to cut rates again in December unless there is clear evidence that inflation will fall faster than expected or that the labor market will cool more rapidly."

The Federal Open Market Committee has already mitigated downside risks to the labor market by cutting rates at the September meeting, she noted. "The remaining risks to employment are ones we can monitor closely and respond to if they are becoming more likely to materialize, not ones that currently warrant further preemptive action," she said.

Developing... check back for updates.

Dear readers: We recognize that politics often intersects with the financial news of the day, so we invite you to click here to join the separate political discussion.

data.title: SPS Commerce tumbles 30% after Q3 revenue, outlook miss bring rating downgrades
data.description:
Shares of SPS Commerce (SPSC) tumbled about 30% premarket on Friday after the company's third quarter revenue, fourth quarter guidance, and initial outlook for 2026 came in below estimates, according to analysts.

Stifel downgraded the shares of SPS — which provides cloud-based supply chain management solutions — to Hold from Buy and cut the price target on the stock to $80 from $150.

"We are downgrading shares of SPSC to Hold (TP to $80) as macro headwinds and spend scrutiny in the retail ecosystem introduce near/mid-term uncertainty around top-line performance. The company's 3Q revenue, 4Q guide, and initial outlook for 2026 came in below consensus, with management pointing to delayed Relationship Management campaigns with retailers, continued supplier challenges and spend scrutiny, and unforeseen seasonality in the newer Revenue Recovery space weighing on the near-term growth outlook," said analysts led by J. Parker Lane.

The analysts added that the company's long-time Executive Vice president and Chief Revenue Officer Dan Juckniess is retiring at the end of the year, with Eduardo Rosini (former Sage, Intuit, and Microsoft) joining as executive vice president and chief commercial officer on Dec. 1.

"While we remain believers in the company's competitive positioning and the size of the addressable opportunity, we believe signs of stabilization/improvement in the end-market are needed for investors to gain confidence in the growth outlook," said Lane and his team.

Cantor downgraded SPS's stock to Neutral from Overweight and reduced the price target to $80 from $135.

"SPSC reported mixed-to-negative 3Q results with Recurring revenue missing consensus (Visible Alpha) on myriad headwinds; profitability made up some of the shortfall, but ultimately FCF missed as well," said analysts led by Matthew VanVliet. "Additionally, mgmt provided weaker 4Q guidance than was implied in the FY25 guide post-2Q, and its initial 2026 growth outlook also missed Street expectations."

The analysts noted that this has led them to reduce their outlook and adjust their near-term thesis, which results in them downgrading the shares and cutting the price target.

VanVliet and his team added that the headwinds experienced in the third quarter will persist into the fourth quarter. The new fourth quarter revenue guidance of $192.7M to $194.7M (+13% to 14% versus Street at 17%) is about $6M below the prior implied guidance.

The analysts said that the initial 2026 growth outlook of 7% to 8% also underwhelmed (versus Street at about 9%) and is being negatively impacted by all the headwinds impacting the fourth quarter.

"We have reservations on whether this outlook is conservative enough given the macro backdrop and apparent list of headwinds that are mostly out of the company's control. To that end, we remain cautious in the speed with which the company will be able to reaccelerate growth in the near term. Positively, despite the lower growth expected in 2026, management continues to expect to expand EBITDA margins by 200 bps," said VanVliet and his team.

data.title: EverCommerce ends strategic review with sale of marketing technology solutions
data.description:
• EverCommerce (EVCM) announced on Friday the sale of its marketing technology solutions to the internet marketing services provider Ignite Visibility.
  • The sale marks the end of the strategic review process announced in March.
  • The market technology solutions, also known as EverConnect, will operate as an integrated business within the Ignite Visibility product set.
